content:
This is so frustrating in Reverse, haha.
I never thought to use the same [[n]] that defines the number of input lines in the actual solution! :(((

Very tricky! But it's so solvable if you can think of it! Having so many values makes it so hard to figure out, because you end up on so many wild goose chases. Nice clash though. :)

It would be nicer on Reverse players if you had less random integers in at least one more test case. Something like [[n]] = 5 and the inputs on one line are "5 10 15 20 25" -> 75
That would have helped a lot!

I still came 2nd with a very hacky solution below. Got 40%. Only one person got 100%.
n = gets.to_i
n.times do
  inputs = gets.split
  a = []
  for j in 0..(n-1)
    a << inputs[j].to_i
  end
  if a.size > 1
    x = a[0]
    if x == a.max
        a = [x]
    else
        a = a[1..]
    end
  end
  p a.sum
end

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear, consice and resolvable with multiple languages

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great little exercise. Very clear

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The game seems correct and good for mastering the basics of a language.

* In Test 4 and Validator 4, n = 5, there are 5 lines, but each line does not contain 5 numbers. It seems inconsistent with the clash description, which states that each line should contain n numbers. Please fix the cases.

Input section
* Please change "Rows Each rows are a string suite of n numbers." to:
<<Next [[n]] lines>> Each line contains [[n]] space-separated positive integers.

Output section
* Please add "<<[[n]] lines>>" at the front.

Stub generator
* Suggest to change "loop n read line:string(256)" to "loop n loopline n integer:int". It is usually better to parse the inputs for the players when parsing is not the focus of the clash.

Thanks.
I suggest adding a large testcase (like n = 999).
Its my first contribution so dont hesitate to give me an advice or tell me how to improve this especially for the thing
As the limit is 10k characters in each case it is not possible, so i changed to 0<n<100 and did a n = 49 testcase. Thanks for your advice !

Hi, thanks a lot for your help, as you and others said i changed a bunch of things so now it should be better. I have a last question if you dont mind, what is the difference between tests and validators ? Thanks again

No problem :)

Please consider changing the stub generator as per my earlier comment.

As for your question:

A clash player can see the tests during a clash, but they cannot see the validataors. However, after they submit their code, their score is based on the validators, not the tests.

That reminds me, you have to change your cases so that tests and validators are similar but different. They should be different, to prevent hardcoding. However they should be similar, to ensure that the requirement is tested.

This is particularly important in Reverse mode, because the players cannot see the statement or the title, and they have to rely on the visible test cases to deduce the requirement. It will be a nasty shock to the player if the validator tests something which cannot be deduced, or is difficult to deduce, based on the tests.

Yeah that make sense, that's why i sometimes got 50% while having my tests at 100% ðŸ˜­. So i did change some values in each validator,  from +- 1 or 2 n at maximum. Do you think i cant release it now ?
It looks good to me. But it's up to you to decide whether you want to hear more feedback from others first or whether you feel ready to release it :)
